paragraphs.text: %md # Use AutoML ## Introduction This lab walks you through the steps to use the AutoML functionality. Estimated Lab Time: 15 minutes ### About AutoML AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) provides built-in data science expertise about data analytics and modeling that you can employ to build machine learning models. ### Objectives In this lab, you will learn how to: * Create data set (wine data) as a Pandas DataFrame and load into ADB * Use `automl.AlgorithmSelection` to rank the in-database algorithms by predicted score metric for classification or regression problems * Use `automl.FeatureSelection` to identify the most relevant feature subsets for the provided training data set and an in-database algorithm * Use `automl.ModelTuning` to tune hyperparameters for the specified algorithm and training data * Use `automl.ModelSelection` to select the top in-database algorithm and then tune the corresponding model in a single function invocation Copyright (c) 2021 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 --- ## Task 1: Import libraries supporting OML4Py 1.1. Run the following script to import the `oml` module, Pandas package, and the `automl` module from oml.

msg.data:
Use AutoML

Introduction

This lab walks you through the steps to use the AutoML functionality.

Estimated Lab Time: 15 minutes

About AutoML

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) provides built-in data science expertise about data analytics and modeling that you can employ to build machine learning models.

Objectives

In this lab, you will learn how to:

  • Create data set (wine data) as a Pandas DataFrame and load into ADB
  • Use automl.AlgorithmSelection to rank the in-database algorithms by predicted score metric for classification or regression problems
  • Use automl.FeatureSelection to identify the most relevant feature subsets for the provided training data set and an in-database algorithm
  • Use automl.ModelTuning to tune hyperparameters for the specified algorithm and training data
  • Use automl.ModelSelection to select the top in-database algorithm and then tune the corresponding model in a single function invocation

Copyright (c) 2021 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

Task 1: Import libraries supporting OML4Py

1.1. Run the following script to import the oml module, Pandas package, and the automl module from oml.

paragraphs.text:
%python

import pandas as pd
import oml
from oml import automl

%md
---
1.2. Use the `oml.sync` function to create an OML Dataframe `CUST_DF` as a proxy for the database table `CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV`.

msg.data: 1.2. Use the oml.sync function to create an OML Dataframe CUST_DF as a proxy for the database table CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV.

paragraphs.text:
%python

CUST_DF = oml.sync("OMLUSER", table = "CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV")
print(CUST_DF.shape)
print(CUST_DF.dtypes)

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Task 2: Automated Algorithm Selection
In this task, you prepare the `CUST_DF` proxy object by separating predictors from the target, as it is standard for Python model building. This produces two new proxy objects that will be used in AutoML functions.

2.1. Run the following script to split the `CUST_DF` data set into `CUST_X` (only containing the predictor attributes) and `CUST_y` (only containing the target attribute `BUY_INSURANCE`).

msg.data:
Task 2: Automated Algorithm Selection

In this task, you prepare the CUST_DF proxy object by separating predictors from the target, as it is standard for Python model building. This produces two new proxy objects that will be used in AutoML functions.

2.1. Run the following script to split the CUST_DF data set into CUST_X (only containing the predictor attributes) and CUST_y (only containing the target attribute BUY_INSURANCE).

paragraphs.text:
%python

CUST_X ,CUST_y  = CUST_DF.drop('BUY_INSURANCE'), CUST_DF['BUY_INSURANCE']

%md
---
2.2. Run the following script to select the top `classification` algorithms for predicting whether a customer will buy insurance (`BUY_INSURANCE`). It displays the top 4 ranked algorithms (requested by the `k=4`) and their `accuracy` (the metric we requested in `score_metric`).  

The script returns Random Forest (rf), Decision Tree (dt), Neural Networks (nn) and Generalized Linear Models (glm) as the Top 4 algorithms, and among these the Random Forest is ranked highest for this problem, and the string `selected_insur_alg` will be used in subsequent AutoML function calls.
 
**Note**: AutoML also supports regression, and the AlgorithmSelection function has other options and metrics that can be found in the documentation links at the bottom of this notebook.

msg.data:
2.2. Run the following script to select the top classification algorithms for predicting whether a customer will buy insurance (BUY_INSURANCE). It displays the top 4 ranked algorithms (requested by the k=4) and their accuracy (the metric we requested in score_metric).

The script returns Random Forest (rf), Decision Tree (dt), Neural Networks (nn) and Generalized Linear Models (glm) as the Top 4 algorithms, and among these the Random Forest is ranked highest for this problem, and the string selected_insur_alg will be used in subsequent AutoML function calls.

Note: AutoML also supports regression, and the AlgorithmSelection function has other options and metrics that can be found in the documentation links at the bottom of this notebook.

paragraphs.text:
%python

as_insur = automl.AlgorithmSelection(mining_function='classification', score_metric='accuracy', parallel=2)

insur_alg_ranking = as_insur.select(CUST_X, CUST_y, k=4, case_id='CUSTOMER_ID')

print("Top ranked algorithms:\n", insur_alg_ranking)

selected_insur_alg = insur_alg_ranking[0][0]

print("\nTop algorithm: ", selected_insur_alg)

%md
## Task 3: Automated Feature Selection

In this task, you determine the features that best support the selected algorithm. First define a FeatureSelection object with score metric `accuracy`. Then call the `reduce` function and specify the desired algorithm, in this case, as determined above and stored in the variable `selected_insur_alg`.

The result will be a a subset of the original columns, to which we will append our case ID (`CUSTOMER_ID`) and use it in the next task.

3.1. Run the following script to define the Feature Selection object `fs_insur` and call the `reduce` function with the selected algorithms and CUST_DF proxy objects:

msg.data:
Task 3: Automated Feature Selection

In this task, you determine the features that best support the selected algorithm. First define a FeatureSelection object with score metric accuracy. Then call the reduce function and specify the desired algorithm, in this case, as determined above and stored in the variable selected_insur_alg.

The result will be a a subset of the original columns, to which we will append our case ID (CUSTOMER_ID) and use it in the next task.

3.1. Run the following script to define the Feature Selection object fs_insur and call the reduce function with the selected algorithms and CUST_DF proxy objects:

paragraphs.text:
%python

fs_insur = automl.FeatureSelection(mining_function = 'classification', score_metric = 'accuracy', parallel=2)

selected_insur_features = fs_insur.reduce(selected_insur_alg, CUST_X, CUST_y, case_id='CUSTOMER_ID')

# Add the CUSTOMER_ID back to the list
selected_insur_features.append('CUSTOMER_ID')

CUST_X_reduced = CUST_X[:,selected_insur_features]

print("Selected columns (plus ID):", CUST_X_reduced.columns)

print("Number of columns: ")
"{} reduced to {}".format(len(CUST_X.columns), len(CUST_X_reduced.columns))

msg.data:
Selected columns (plus ID): ['MARITAL_STATUS', 'CREDIT_BALANCE', 'CUSTOMER_TENURE', 'MORTGAGE_AMOUNT', 'BANK_FUNDS', 'NUM_DEPENDENTS', 'HAS_CHILDREN', 'INCOME', 'GENDER', 'CREDIT_CARD_LIMITS', 'HOME_OWNERSHIP', 'NUM_ONLINE_TRANS', 'MONTHLY_CHECKS', 'NUM_TRANS_KIOSK', 'AGE', 'MONEY_MONTLY_OVERDRAWN', 'TOTAL_AUTOM_PAYMENTS', 'NUM_TRANS_TELLER', 'CHECKING_BALANCE', 'NUM_TRANS_ATM', 'NUM_MORTGAGES', 'CAR_OWNERSHIP', 'CUSTOMER_ID']
Number of columns: 
'30 reduced to 23'

paragraphs.text:
%md
### **Try it Yourself**
Try other algorithms, such as `Decision Tree` or `Neural Network` in the first argument of the reduce function by replacing the string **selected_insur_alg** for **'dt'** or **'nn'** (with quotes), and see if different columns are selected.

msg.data:
Try it Yourself

Try other algorithms, such as Decision Tree or Neural Network in the first argument of the reduce function by replacing the string selected_insur_alg for 'dt' or 'nn' (with quotes), and see if different columns are selected.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Task 4: Automated Model Tuning
At this point, you are ready to build and tune the models you want to use.

First, you define a `ModelTuning` object for classification.
Then, invoke `tune`, which builds and tunes the best model using the algorithm selected above (stored as `selected_insur_alg`) and the reduced data features (stored as `CUST_X_reduced`).

Model tuning returns a dictionary with the best model and the evaluation results of the other models tried. This also contains a list of the hyperparameter choices tried and their corresponding score.

4.1. Run the following script to define the model tuning object `mt_insur` for classification and invoke the `tune` function on it.

**NOTE:** It may take around a minute or two to run depending on the configuration

msg.data:
Task 4: Automated Model Tuning

At this point, you are ready to build and tune the models you want to use.

First, you define a ModelTuning object for classification.
Then, invoke tune, which builds and tunes the best model using the algorithm selected above (stored as selected_insur_alg) and the reduced data features (stored as CUST_X_reduced).

Model tuning returns a dictionary with the best model and the evaluation results of the other models tried. This also contains a list of the hyperparameter choices tried and their corresponding score.

4.1. Run the following script to define the model tuning object mt_insur for classification and invoke the tune function on it.

NOTE: It may take around a minute or two to run depending on the configuration

paragraphs.text:
%python

mt_insur = automl.ModelTuning(mining_function = 'classification', parallel=2)

insur_tuned = mt_insur.tune(selected_insur_alg, CUST_X_reduced, CUST_y, case_id='CUSTOMER_ID')

top_insur_tuned = insur_tuned['best_model']
top_insur_tuned

paragraphs.text:
%md
---
4.2. Run the following script to **list the hyperparameters and their values** that were tried for the `top two models`, along with the corresponding model's score metric value (`accuracy`).

msg.data: 4.2. Run the following script to list the hyperparameters and their values that were tried for the top two models, along with the corresponding model's score metric value (accuracy).

paragraphs.text:
%python

hyper_tuned = insur_tuned['all_evals']

print(*hyper_tuned[:2], sep='\n')

msg.data:
(0.8426247886495626, {'CLAS_MAX_SUP_BINS': 32, 'CLAS_WEIGHTS_BALANCED': 'OFF', 'RFOR_MTRY': 15, 'RFOR_NUM_TREES': 20, 'RFOR_SAMPLING_RATIO': 0.5, 'TREE_IMPURITY_METRIC': 'TREE_IMPURITY_ENTROPY', 'TREE_TERM_MAX_DEPTH': 16, 'TREE_TERM_MINPCT_NODE': 0.05, 'TREE_TERM_MINPCT_SPLIT': 0.1})
(0.8426247886495626, {'CLAS_MAX_SUP_BINS': 32, 'CLAS_WEIGHTS_BALANCED': 'ON', 'RFOR_MTRY': 15, 'RFOR_NUM_TREES': 20, 'RFOR_SAMPLING_RATIO': 0.5, 'TREE_IMPURITY_METRIC': 'TREE_IMPURITY_ENTROPY', 'TREE_TERM_MAX_DEPTH': 16, 'TREE_TERM_MINPCT_NODE': 0.05, 'TREE_TERM_MINPCT_SPLIT': 0.1})

paragraphs.text:
%md
---
4.3. Run the following script to **list the hyperparameters and their values** that were tried for the `top ten models`, along with the corresponding model's score metric value (`accuracy`) in a better formatted way.

msg.data: 4.3. Run the following script to list the hyperparameters and their values that were tried for the top ten models, along with the corresponding model's score metric value (accuracy) in a better formatted way.

paragraphs.text:
%python

tuning_report = pd.concat([pd.DataFrame([i+1 for i in range(10)], columns=['Ranking']), 
                           pd.DataFrame(hyper_tuned[:10], columns=['Accuracy','Model_Settings_Tried'])], 
                           axis=1)

z.show(tuning_report.round(6))

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
---
4.3. Run the following script to specify a custom search space to explore for model building using the `param_space` argument to the `tune` function. With this specification, model tuning will narrow the set of important hyperparameter values.
**Note**: For illustration purposes we are using a different scoring metric, `f1_macro`.

msg.data:
4.3. Run the following script to specify a custom search space to explore for model building using the param_space argument to the tune function. With this specification, model tuning will narrow the set of important hyperparameter values.
Note: For illustration purposes we are using a different scoring metric, f1_macro.

paragraphs.text:
%python

search_space={'RFOR_SAMPLING_RATIO': {'type': 'continuous', 'range': [0.05, 0.5]},
              'RFOR_NUM_TREES': {'type': 'discrete', 'range': [50, 55]},
              'TREE_IMPURITY_METRIC': {'type': 'categorical',
                                       'range': ['TREE_IMPURITY_ENTROPY', 'TREE_IMPURITY_GINI']},}

mt2_insur = automl.ModelTuning(mining_function='classification', score_metric='f1_macro', parallel=2)

insur_tuned2 = mt2_insur.tune('rf', CUST_X, CUST_y, case_id='CUSTOMER_ID', param_space=search_space)

score, params = insur_tuned2['all_evals'][0]
"{:.2}".format(score)

print('The top model has an f1_macro of ',score.round(4),' and parameters ',params)

top_insur_tuned2 = insur_tuned2['best_model']
top_insur_tuned2

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Task 5: Automated Model Selection
As a short cut, you may choose to go directly to model selection on the training data. Model Selection automatically selects the top ranked algorithm (using Algorithm Selection) from the set of supported algorithms, then builds, tunes, and returns the model.

5.1. Run the following script to define a` ModelSelection` object and invoke `select` for automatically building the best model on the `CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV` dataset. The final model is displayed.

**Note**: In the script below the option `k=1` (the default is 3) tells ModelSelection to only return the top model, and the option `cv=2` (the default is 'auto') requests that it uses 2 folds for a Stratified kFold Cross-Validation.  Mode details in the documentation links at the bottom of this notebook.

*NOTE:* It may take around three to four minutes to run depending on the configuration

msg.data:
Task 5: Automated Model Selection

As a short cut, you may choose to go directly to model selection on the training data. Model Selection automatically selects the top ranked algorithm (using Algorithm Selection) from the set of supported algorithms, then builds, tunes, and returns the model.

5.1. Run the following script to define aModelSelection object and invoke select for automatically building the best model on the CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV dataset. The final model is displayed.

Note: In the script below the option k=1 (the default is 3) tells ModelSelection to only return the top model, and the option cv=2 (the default is 'auto') requests that it uses 2 folds for a Stratified kFold Cross-Validation. Mode details in the documentation links at the bottom of this notebook.

NOTE: It may take around three to four minutes to run depending on the configuration

paragraphs.text:
%python

ms_cust = automl.ModelSelection(mining_function = 'classification', parallel=2)

top_model = ms_cust.select(CUST_X, CUST_y, case_id='CUSTOMER_ID', k=1, cv=2)

print('The top model is of the type: ', top_model[1])

print('Model details:')

top_model[0]
